sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a vaporization reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change of vaporization of water at 373 K according to the following data:

H2(g) + O2(g) → H2O(l)     ΔH° = -285.8 kJ/mol

H2O(l) → H2O(g)             ΔH° = +40.7 kJ/mol

Note: The answer should be in units of kJ/mol.
message_2:
The standard enthalpy change of vaporization of water at 373 K can be found using the given data. We have the following reactions:

1) H2(g) + 1/2 O2(g) → H2O(l)     ΔH° = -285.8 kJ/mol
2) H2O(l) → H2O(g)             ΔH° = +40.7 kJ/mol

To find the enthalpy change of vaporization, we need to consider the second reaction:

H2O(l) → H2O(g)             ΔH° = +40.7 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change of vaporization of water at 373 K is +40.7 kJ/mol.
